questions.text: Which of the following tissues are dependent on insulin for glucose uptake? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Muscle and adipose tissues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • GLUT-4 glucose transporter is insulin dependent and is the only GLUT present in muscle and adipose tissues. So, muscles and adipose tissues are totally dependent on Insulin for glucose uptake.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Liver: The liver uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. GLUT-2 allows the liver to take up glucose and store it as glycogen or use it for energy production, independent of insulin.
  • • Option A. Liver:
  • • Option B. Pancreas: The pancreas also uses GLUT-2 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. In the pancreas, GLUT-2 plays a role in sensing blood glucose levels and regulating insulin secretion.
  • • Option B. Pancreas:
  • • Option D. Placenta: The placenta uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3 transporters for glucose uptake, which are not insulin-dependent. These transporters facilitate the basal uptake of glucose to support the energy needs of the placenta and fetus.
  • • Option D. Placenta:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with severe hypoglycemia and fatty liver. Which biochemical changes best explain this presentation? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio and increased gluconeogenesis

options.label: B
options.text: Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio and decreased gluconeogenesis

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased fatty acid oxidation and increased glycolysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio and decreased gluconeogenesis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increased NADH/NAD+ ratio and decreased gluconeogenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand how ethanol metabolism's effect on NADH/NAD+ ratio creates a cascade of metabolic derangements:
  • ➤ Inhibition of gluconeogenesis leading to hypoglycemia Decreased fatty acid oxidation and increased esterification causing fatty liver These changes are primarily driven by the altered redox state (increased NADH/NAD+ ratio)
  • ➤ Inhibition of gluconeogenesis leading to hypoglycemia
  • ➤ Decreased fatty acid oxidation and increased esterification causing fatty liver
  • ➤ These changes are primarily driven by the altered redox state (increased NADH/NAD+ ratio)

questions.text: Although Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 are derived from the same gene but are finally translated into separate proteins. This is mainly due to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) RNA editing

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is due to RNA editing. In the intestine, a specific cytidine in the mRNA for Apo B is deaminated to uridine, which changes the codon from one encoding amino acid to a stop codon. This results in the production of a shorter protein, Apo B 48. In the liver, this editing does not occur, so the full-length Apo B 100 is produced.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. DNA Gene Mutation in Intestines: Incorrect. The difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100 is not due to a DNA gene mutation specific to the intestines. Both proteins are derived from the same gene, and the variation in their production is not the result of a DNA mutation.
  • • Option A. DNA Gene Mutation in Intestines:
  • • Option B. Point Mutation in Liver: Incorrect. Similarly, the production of these two forms of apolipoprotein B is not due to a point mutation in the liver. The liver produces Apo B 100, but this is not because of a mutation in the hepatic DNA.
  • • Option B. Point Mutation in Liver:
  • • Option C. DNA Gene Splicing: Incorrect. While alternative splicing is a common mechanism in generating protein diversity, it is not the process responsible for the difference between Apo B 48 and Apo B 100.
  • • Option C. DNA Gene Splicing:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Apo-B-48 is the major apoprotein of chylomicrons. It is synthesized only in the intestinal cells. Apo-B100 and apo-B48 are products of the same gene, but in the intestine, the mRNA undergoes editing and so produces the B48 protein. It is named so because it is only 40% of the size of B100.
  • ➤ Apo-B-48 is the major apoprotein of chylomicrons.
  • ➤ It is synthesized only in the intestinal cells.
  • ➤ Apo-B100 and apo-B48 are products of the same gene, but in the intestine, the mRNA undergoes editing and so produces the B48 protein.
  • ➤ It is named so because it is only 40% of the size of B100.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 249
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 249

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated directly or indirectly by? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition exhibited by A. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Competitive inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Competitive inhibition is identified by an increased Km and unchanged Vmax, with intersecting lines on the y-axis of the Lineweaver-Burk plot

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic pathways occurs exclusively in mitochondria? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TCA cycle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the strict compartmentalization of metabolic pathways:
  • ➤ TCA cycle is exclusively mitochondrial Some pathways are exclusively cytoplasmic (glycolysis, fatty acid synthesis) Some pathways occur in multiple compartments (beta-oxidation in mitochondria and peroxisomes) This compartmentalization allows for proper regulation and prevents futile cycling of metabolic pathways
  • ➤ TCA cycle is exclusively mitochondrial
  • ➤ Some pathways are exclusively cytoplasmic (glycolysis, fatty acid synthesis)
  • ➤ Some pathways occur in multiple compartments (beta-oxidation in mitochondria and peroxisomes)
  • ➤ This compartmentalization allows for proper regulation and prevents futile cycling of metabolic pathways

questions.text: The three most important enzymes regulating the Citric Acid Cycle include all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aconitase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The three rate-limiting enzymes/steps in the TCA cycle are specifically listed as: 1) Citrate synthase, 2) α-KG DH (alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase), and 3) Isocitrate Dehydrogenase. Aconitase catalyzes the conversion of citrate to isocitrate but is not mentioned among the key regulatory enzymes of the cycle.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Citrate synthase : This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. It is specifically identified as one of the regulatory enzymes.
  • • Option A. Citrate synthase
  • • Option B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. This enzyme is a key regulatory component.
  • • Option B. Isocitrate dehydrogenase:
  • • Option C. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: This is incorrect as an answer because it is one of the three main regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle. It is clearly identified as one of the regulatory steps.
  • • Option C. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three major regulatory enzymes of the TCA cycle are citrate synthase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, while aconitase serves as a non-regulatory enzyme in the pathway.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a urea cycle disorder, which is inherited as an X-linked trait. Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency . Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet. To reduce ammonia levels, glutamate combines with ammonia to form glutamine. Thus, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.
  • ➤ X-linked
  • ➤ Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency
  • ➤ Urea cycle disorders
  • ➤ Urea cycle disorders

questions.text: Highest thermic effect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proteins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The thermic effect of food (TEF) refers to the increase in energy expenditure that occurs during the digestion, absorption, and metabolism of nutrients in the body. This effect varies depending on the macronutrient composition of the food consumed.

questions.text: DNA packing is done by? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Histone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins
  • ➤ Nucleosomes = DNA + Histone proteins
  • ➤ Histone proteins are rich in basic AA such as lysine and arginine, so, carry a positive charge. While DNA due to PO 4 2- groups has large negative charge. So, in nucleosomes, DNA and histones are tightly packed due to interaction between these opposite charges.

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 351

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lecithin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RDS is a common condition in premature infants due to inadequate surfactant production, particularly the deficiency of lecithin. The educational objective is to understand the etiology of RDS and its association with surfactant components, specifically lecithin. This knowledge is crucial for healthcare professionals involved in the care of neonates, as RDS can have serious respiratory consequences in premature infants and requires appropriate management and support.

questions.text: A patient presented with dermatitis and loss of appetite. He also gives a frequent history of diarrhoea. On examination, alopecia also seen and patient has observed that he has delayed wound healing. This patient is most likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The symptoms described, including dermatitis, loss of appetite, diarrhea, alopecia, and delayed wound healing, are consistent with a disease known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica due to zinc deficiency. Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including immune function, wound healing, and maintenance of skin and hair. Symptoms of this disease are:
  • ➤ Simultaneous diarrhoea + dermatitis Inflammation around nose, mouth, anus, cheeks, elbow etc. It also occurs in some infants after weaning from breast milk as breast milk has picolinic acid (piconilic acid increases Zn absorption from intestine)
  • ➤ Simultaneous diarrhoea + dermatitis
  • ➤ Inflammation around nose, mouth, anus, cheeks, elbow etc.
  • ➤ It also occurs in some infants after weaning from breast milk as breast milk has picolinic acid (piconilic acid increases Zn absorption from intestine)
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 414
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Medical biochemistry 3rd edition Page no. 414

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for breastfeeding is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Galactosemia is a rare genetic disorder where the body cannot properly metabolize galactose, a sugar present in breast milk and many other foods. Infants with galactosemia are unable to break down galactose and its accumulation can lead to severe complications. Therefore, breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication for infants with galactosemia, and they require a special galactose-free formula.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. HIV: This option is incorrect. While HIV can be transmitted through breast milk, the transmission risk can be significantly reduced by antiretroviral therapy (ART) and other precautions. In certain situations, such as in resource-limited settings where safe alternatives to breastfeeding are not available, the benefits of breastfeeding may outweigh the risks of HIV transmission. However, in areas where safe and affordable alternatives are accessible, avoiding breastfeeding is generally recommended for infants born to HIV-positive mothers.
  • • Option B.
  • • HIV:
  • • Option C. Hepatitis B: This option is incorrect. Breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants born to mothers with hepatitis B. Transmission of hepatitis B through breast milk is considered low, and the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that infants receive the hepatitis B vaccine and a dose of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) within 12 hours of birth to prevent transmission. Breastfeeding can generally continue in these cases.
  • • Option C.
  • • Hepatitis B:
  • • Option D. Cytomegalovirus infection: This option is incorrect. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can be transmitted through breast milk, but the transmission risk can be reduced. In most cases, breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants with CMV infection. Precautions such as pasteurization of breast milk or using frozen breast milk from before the infection occurred can be taken to reduce the risk of transmission.
  • • Option D.
  • • Cytomegalovirus infection:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question aims to identify conditions where breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated. Understanding absolute contraindications for breastfeeding is crucial for ensuring the safety and health of both the neonate and the mother. In certain medical conditions, breastfeeding can pose significant health risks to the infant, necessitating alternative feeding methods.

questions.text: A patient was presented to OPD with features of collagen vascular disorder. Which of the following deficits is most likely to be associated with defective collagen formation? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both A & B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Deficiencies in both ascorbic acid and the minerals copper and iron collectively contribute to defective collagen formation. Ascorbic acid deficiency impairs the hydroxylation of collagen, while copper and iron deficiencies affect collagen cross-linking and stability.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ascorbic Acid: Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) is crucial for collagen synthesis. It acts as a cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, enzymes necessary for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen. Deficiency of Vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by weakened collagen and symptoms like bleeding gums and poor wound healing.
  • • Option A. Ascorbic Acid:
  • • Option B. Copper and Iron: Copper is a cofactor for lysyl oxidase, an enzyme involved in the cross-linking of collagen fibers, essential for the strength and integrity of collagen. Iron is also involved in the hydroxylation of proline and lysine in collagen synthesis. Deficiencies in these minerals can impair collagen formation and structure.
  • • Option B. Copper and Iron:
  • • Option D. Zinc & Magnesium: While zinc and magnesium are important for overall health and participate in numerous enzymatic reactions, they are not primarily associated with collagen synthesis or cross-linking in the same direct manner as ascorbic acid, copper, and iron.
  • • Option D. Zinc & Magnesium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post translational modification of collagen on proline and lysine residue is required for its proper hydrogen bond formation and crosslinking which provide strength to collagen fibers. These reactions require vitamin C, copper and iron as cofactors for the enzyme involved in these processes.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548

questions.text: Which of the following activate glycogen phosphorylase? ( INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Calcium ions play a role in the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. When there is a need for energy, an increase in intracellular calcium levels can activate glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium ions bind to calmodulin, which, in turn, activates phosphorylase kinase. Phosphorylase kinase then phosphorylates and activates glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: Calcium-mediated activation of glycogen phosphorylase is part of the fight-or-flight response, ensuring a rapid release of glucose for energy during periods of stress or physical activity.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Glucose 6-Phosphate:
  • • Option B.
  • • Glucose 6-Phosphate:
  • • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high. Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation: Glucose 6-phosphate is a product of the glycolytic pathway and is an indicator of sufficient energy within the cell. High levels of glucose 6-phosphate inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. Glycogen phosphorylase is typically activated when glucose levels are low and energy demand is high.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: The presence of glucose 6-phosphate signals that the cell has adequate energy reserves and does not need to break down glycogen.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Option C. Glucose:
  • • Option
  • • C.
  • • Glucose:
  • • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen. Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Explanation: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose can have an inhibitory effect on glycogen phosphorylase because it indicates that there is sufficient glucose available for energy needs, reducing the need to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: Elevated glucose levels signal that there is no immediate need to activate glycogen phosphorylase.
  • • Relevance:
  • • Option D. High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):
  • • Option
  • • D.
  • • High ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):
  • • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen. Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.
  • • Explanation: High levels of ATP can inhibit glycogen phosphorylase. ATP is a molecule that stores energy, and when ATP levels are high, it indicates that the cell has sufficient energy reserves. In this context, glycogen phosphorylase would not be activated to break down glycogen.
  • • Explanation:
  • • Relevance: High ATP levels signal that there is no immediate need for additional energy from glycogenolysis.
  • • Relevance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen Phosphorylase is first and RLE of glycogenolysis. It transfers P i , uses PLP (B 6 ) and breaks α (1 à 4) bonds from one end until 4 glucose residues are left at branch point. End-product is Glucose 1–P (90%). It exists in two forms b and a. which is regulated by various mechanism shown as:

questions.text: Which of the following is not glucogenic?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acetyl coenzyme A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetyl CoA is not a glucogenic compound as it cannot be directly converted into glucose, unlike oxaloacetate, lactate, and pyruvate, which are glucogenic and contribute to glucose synthesis.
  • ➤ Substrates of gluconeogenesis (mostly 3C)
  • ➤ Substrates of gluconeogenesis (mostly 3C)
  • ➤ Pyruvate (3C) Lactate (3C) Propionic acid (3C) Glycerol (3C) Glucogenic amino acids (18 amino acids) Both Ketogenic & Glucogenic amino acids Any TCA Intermediate (forms oxaloacetate which can enter gluconeogenesis)
  • ➤ Pyruvate (3C)
  • ➤ Lactate (3C)
  • ➤ Propionic acid (3C)
  • ➤ Glycerol (3C)
  • ➤ Glucogenic amino acids (18 amino acids)
  • ➤ Both Ketogenic & Glucogenic amino acids
  • ➤ Any TCA Intermediate (forms oxaloacetate which can enter gluconeogenesis)

questions.text: RBC uses which of the following substances during fasting/starvation? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RBCs always uses glucose whether it is fed state or fasting/starvation state because RBCs lack mitochondria. As ketone body utilization and fatty acid oxidation both take place in mitochondria so, RBCs cannot use fatty acids & ketone bodies as energy source.
  • ➤ Table: Substrates utilized for energy production
  • ➤ Table: Substrates utilized for energy production
  • ➤ Fetal heart and also in case of heart failure, main fuel is Glucose. Brain cannot use FA as FAs cannot cross blood brain barrier.
  • ➤ Fetal heart and also in case of heart failure, main fuel is Glucose.
  • ➤ Brain cannot use FA as FAs cannot cross blood brain barrier.
  • ➤ Ref-Harper 31 st e/p 138-139
  • ➤ Ref-Harper 31 st e/p 138-139

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: What is the order of drawing blood sample in vials/vacutainers: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey.
  • • Different vials or vacutainers are used to collect specific types of blood samples for various laboratory tests. Each color-coded tube is designed to preserve and stabilize specific components of the blood. The correct order mentioned above follows this sequence:
  • • 1. Blue: The blue-top tube is typically used for coagulation tests that require blood to be collected in citrate anticoagulant. The citrate in the tube helps prevent blood clotting by binding calcium.
  • • 1. Blue:
  • • 2. Red: The red-top tube does not contain any anticoagulant and is commonly used for collecting blood samples for various tests, including serum chemistry, blood bank, and serology. After allowing the blood to clot, it is centrifuged, and the resulting serum is used for analysis.
  • • 2. Red:
  • • 3. Lavender: The lavender-top tube contains EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) as an anticoagulant. It is used for collecting whole blood for complete blood count (CBC), blood typing, and other hematological tests. EDTA helps preserve the blood cell morphology.
  • • 3. Lavender:
  • • 4. Grey: The grey-top tube contains an anticoagulant called potassium oxalate or sodium fluoride. It is used primarily for glucose testing and helps preserve blood glucose levels by inhibiting glycolysis.
  • • 4. Grey:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue (coagulation tests), Red (serum tests), Lavender (hematology tests), and Grey (glucose tests) to ensure accurate test results and avoid cross-contamination.

questions.text: The Warburg effect refers to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aerobic glycolysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Warburg effect is characterized by the increased utilization of glucose via glycolysis to generate ATP, even in the presence of adequate oxygen levels. This phenomenon is commonly observed in cancer cells, which rely on aerobic glycolysis instead of the more efficient mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation. This metabolic reprogramming supports the rapid growth and proliferation of cancer cells by providing intermediates for biosynthetic pathways, despite being less efficient in terms of ATP production.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Anaerobic glycolysis: This occurs in the absence of oxygen, which is not the characteristic feature of the Warburg effect.
  • • Option B. Anaerobic glycolysis:
  • • Option C. Sustained angiogenesis: This refers to the formation of new blood vessels, which is important in cancer progression but is not the defining feature of the Warburg effect.
  • • Option C. Sustained angiogenesis:
  • • Option D. Evasion of apoptosis: This is a hallmark of cancer cells, allowing them to avoid programmed cell death, but it is not related to the metabolic changes described by the Warburg effect.
  • • Option D. Evasion of apoptosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Warburg effect is the enhanced conversion of glucose to lactate even in the presence of normal levels of oxygen, known as aerobic glycolysis, commonly observed in cancer cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding telomerase? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Involved in DNA repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Telomerase is an enzyme with reverse transcriptase activity, present only in eukaryotes, and is crucial for maintaining chromosome length by adding telomeric repeats. It is not directly involved in DNA repair.

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairment and early death in affected children.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability and frequent episodes of muscle cramps during physical activity. The mother notes that the child often vomits after exercise. Muscle biopsy shows excess glycogen accumulation. What enzyme is most likely deficient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glycogen phosphorylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle's disease) is characterized by exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and exercise-induced myoglobinuria due to inability to break down muscle glycogen during exercise. The presence of excess muscle glycogen on biopsy helps differentiate it from other metabolic myopathies.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Albinism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the marked bond in Orange? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hydrogen bond

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrogen bonds between purine and pyrimidine bases stabilize the double helix structure of DNA.

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition: (INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aspartate and Glutamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibrinopeptide A is a peptide that is cleaved from fibrinogen during blood clotting to form fibrin. Fibrin is a key component of blood clots and is responsible for stopping bleeding from injured blood vessels. Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues .
  • ➤ Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues

questions.text: Which Biochemical method is exploited for monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Purine salvage pathway

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The purine salvage pathway is critical in hybridoma technology for monoclonal antibody production, enabling the selection of viable hybridoma cells in HAT medium.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency, indicated by reduced glutathione reductase activity, can cause symptoms such as a fissured tongue, cheilosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A person presented with neurological manifestations mimicking UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) palsy and sensory neuropathy. The patient was pale and investigations revealed anemia. The probable micronutrient deficiency is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, including UMN-like signs and sensory neuropathy, due to its essential role in nerve function. This deficiency can result from dietary inadequacy or malabsorption, leading to anemia and neurological complications. It's crucial to recognize the clinical presentation of vitamin B12 deficiency to provide appropriate treatment and prevent long-term neurological damage.

questions.text: The Pentose Phosphate Pathway is significant for the synthesis of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both B and C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP), also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt, plays a critical role in cellular metabolism by generating NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate. NADPH is crucial for reductive biosynthesis reactions, such as fatty acid and nucleotide synthesis, and for maintaining reduced glutathione levels to protect against oxidative stress. Ribose-5-phosphate is essential for nucleotide and nucleic acid synthesis. The PPP occurs in the cytosol and consists of two phases: the oxidative phase, which produces NADPH, and the non-oxidative phase, which generates ribose precursors. Notably, no ATP is directly consumed or produced in the Pentose Phosphate Pathway.
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option A. ATP: The Pentose Phosphate Pathway does not generate ATP. Instead, it focuses on producing NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate.
  • • Option A. ATP:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Pentose Phosphate Pathway is vital for the production of NADPH and ribose precursors, essential for reductive biosynthesis and nucleotide synthesis, respectively.

questions.text: A patient has microcytic hypochromic anemia and was observed to have delayed wound healing after a minor surgery. He gives history of gum bleeding also. He is most likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is crucial for collagen synthesis, a vital component of skin and vascular tissues. Deficiency leads to scurvy, which manifests with symptoms like gum bleeding, poor wound healing, and anemia. The anemia is typically normocytic but can be microcytic due to associated blood loss and iron deficiency.
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 548

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) RNA editing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RNA editing, such as the editing of the apolipoprotein B mRNA, can involve modifications that do not occur in the 5' to 3' direction, unlike transcription, DNA replication, and DNA repair, which all proceed in the 5' to 3' direction.

questions.text: The rate-limiting enzyme of HMP shunt is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rate Limiting Enzymes
  • ➤ Rate Limiting Enzymes

questions.text: Which of the following has highest glycemic index: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Glucose is often used as the standard reference for measuring the glycemic index, with a value set at 100. It is absorbed rapidly into the bloodstream, causing a quick and significant increase in blood sugar levels. Thus, it has the highest glycemic index among the options listed.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Fructose: Fructose has a lower glycemic index compared to glucose. This is because fructose is metabolized differently, primarily in the liver, and leads to a slower and lower rise in blood glucose levels compared to glucose.
  • • Option B. Fructose:
  • • Option C. Sucrose: Sucrose, or table sugar, is a disaccharide composed of glucose and fructose. Its glycemic index is lower than that of pure glucose because the presence of fructose moderates the overall blood sugar response.
  • • Option C. Sucrose:
  • • Option D. Sugar Alcohols: Sugar alcohols, such as xylitol, sorbitol, and mannitol, generally have lower glycemic indices than glucose. They are absorbed more slowly and incompletely in the intestine, leading to a lesser impact on blood sugar levels.
  • • Option D. Sugar Alcohols:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycemic index (GI) - This is the increase in blood glucose after the test dose of a carbohydrate compared with that of an equivalent amount of glucose. GI is a value assigned to foods based on how slowly or how quickly those foods cause an increase in blood glucose levels.
  • ➤ Glycemic index (GI)
  • ➤ GI measures sugar in the blood (only glucose). It does not measure fructose or glucose - fructose blends. The highest glycemic index is for glucose & galactose (Also, maltose, trehalose & isomaltose get converted to glucose, so they also have high GI). Also, lactose is broken down to glucose and galactose, so has high GI. This is because glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestine via SGLT-1, which is active transport and absorbs all of glucose & galactose, even against the concentration gradient. Fructose and sugar alcohols have less glycemic index because they are not absorbed completely (because glucose transporter is GLUT-5, which absorbs fructose only down the concentration gradient). HFCS (High Fructose Corn Syrup)- 58% glucose, Sucrose (50% glucose) gets split into glucose, so have high GI (HFCS & Sucrose has fructose as the other component).
  • ➤ GI measures sugar in the blood (only glucose). It does not measure fructose or glucose - fructose blends.
  • ➤ The highest glycemic index is for glucose & galactose (Also, maltose, trehalose & isomaltose get converted to glucose, so they also have high GI). Also, lactose is broken down to glucose and galactose, so has high GI. This is because glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestine via SGLT-1, which is active transport and absorbs all of glucose & galactose, even against the concentration gradient.
  • ➤ highest glycemic index
  • ➤ glucose & galactose
  • ➤ Fructose and sugar alcohols have less glycemic index because they are not absorbed completely (because glucose transporter is GLUT-5, which absorbs fructose only down the concentration gradient).
  • ➤ Fructose and sugar alcohols
  • ➤ less glycemic index
  • ➤ HFCS (High Fructose Corn Syrup)- 58% glucose, Sucrose (50% glucose) gets split into glucose, so have high GI (HFCS & Sucrose has fructose as the other component).
  • ➤ GI of Glucose = 100 % or 1 GI of Fructose = 25 % GI of Sucrose = 65 %
  • ➤ GI of Glucose = 100 % or 1
  • ➤ GI of Glucose
  • ➤ GI of Fructose = 25 %
  • ➤ GI of Fructose
  • ➤ GI of Sucrose = 65 %
  • ➤ GI of Sucrose
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 528
  • ➤ Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 528

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of dermatitis, diarrhea, and cognitive decline. Which micronutrient deficiency is most likely responsible? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is primarily caused by niacin deficiency.

questions.text: Positive charge in thick ascending loop of Henle is maintained by recirculation of which cation: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) K+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The thick ascending loop of Henle (TAL) is impermeable to water but there is active reabsorption of Na, Cl and K. The cotransporter in membrane of TAL is responsible for reabsorption of 1/3 of both Na and Cl in the body. On the basolateral side there is Na/K ATPase pump which throws sodium out and K in. This K + is transported back into lumen through Renal outer medullary K + channel (ROMK) channel for it to be recirculated.
  • ➤ Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4220766/
  • ➤ Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4220766/

questions.text: This condition is treated by supplementation of which of the following? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, is treated with niacin or nicotinamide supplementation

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day. What’s the source of glucose in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded). After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer).
  • ➤ Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer).
  • ➤ Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 176
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 176

questions.text: A young child presents with angular stomatitis, cheilosis, and glossitis. Further examination reveals corneal vascularization and seborrheic dermatitis. What vitamin deficiency best explains this clinical presentation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Riboflavin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Riboflavin deficiency primarily affects rapidly regenerating tissues like mucous membranes and epithelial surfaces, leading to characteristic orofacial manifestations (cheilosis, angular stomatitis, glossitis) and ocular changes (corneal vascularization). This helps differentiate it from other B vitamin deficiencies which have distinct clinical patterns.

questions.text: Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dicoumarol inhibits the action of vitamin K by competitively inhibiting vitamin K reductase, preventing the regeneration of active vitamin K necessary for blood clotting.

questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). This mechanism corrects errors that typically occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes result in microsatellite instability and contribute to the development of various cancers at an early age. In contrast, Homologous Repair (HR) defects are associated with other genetic disorders and cancers, including Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, breast cancer, and Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect for this context as it deals with the repair of bulky helix-distorting lesions caused by UV radiation and chemicals, leading to diseases like Xeroderma pigmentosum.
  • • Option B. Nucleotide excision repair:
  • • Option C. Base excision repair: Incorrect as it fixes small non-helix-distorting bases caused by spontaneous or induced changes, leading to conditions like MUTYH-associated polyposis when defective.
  • • Option C. Base excision repair:
  • • Option D. Homologous recombinant repair: Incorrect for HNPCC. It repairs double-strand breaks or interstrand cross-links in DNA, not typically involved in the pathogenesis of HNPCC.
  • • Option D. Homologous recombinant repair:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 370
  • ➤ Ref - Harper 31 st e/pg. 370

questions.text: Alkali disease of livestock is caused by an excess of which of the following minerals? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Selenium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkali disease in livestock is caused by chronic selenium toxicity, leading to liver cirrhosis, hoof malformations, loss of hair, and emaciation. This condition is distinct from the effects of other mineral toxicities or deficiencies.

questions.text: Match the following transport proteins with their primary ligands: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1c, 2b, 3a, 4d

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand specific plasma transport proteins and their primary ligands:
  • ➤ Ceruloplasmin is the major copper transport protein Transferrin specifically binds and transports iron RBP is essential for vitamin A transport Transcortin (CBG) is the primary cortisol carrier
  • ➤ Ceruloplasmin is the major copper transport protein
  • ➤ Transferrin specifically binds and transports iron
  • ➤ RBP is essential for vitamin A transport
  • ➤ Transcortin (CBG) is the primary cortisol carrier

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 880 Kcal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is a method used to deliver nutrients directly into the bloodstream when patients cannot use their gastrointestinal tract. The caloric value of the nutrients provided in the TPN bag can be calculated based on the caloric content of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.
  • ➤ Caloric Values:
  • ➤ Caloric Values:
  • ➤ Carbohydrates (glucose): 4 KCal/g Proteins (amino acids): Approximately 4 KCal/g Fats (lipids): 9 KCal/g
  • ➤ Carbohydrates (glucose): 4 KCal/g
  • ➤ Carbohydrates (glucose):
  • ➤ Proteins (amino acids): Approximately 4 KCal/g
  • ➤ Proteins (amino acids):
  • ➤ Fats (lipids): 9 KCal/g
  • ➤ Fats (lipids):

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tryptophan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ UV absorption occur due to conjugated double bonds in the ring. So, to increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm, alanine should be replaced by any aromatic amino acids such as Phenylalanine, tyrosine and tryptophan. Out of these, tryptophan absorbs ultraviolet light about ten times more efficiently than either phenylalanine or tyrosine due to presence of two rings in its side chain compared to only one in other two amino acids.
  • ➤ Out of these, tryptophan
  • ➤ All other amino acid given here do not absorb UV light due to lack of conjugated double bonds.
  • ➤ Guanine is nitrogenous base not amino acid. It absorbs at 260nm.
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Additional information:
  • ➤ Absorbance of compounds:
  • ➤ Absorbance of compounds:
  • ➤ Proteins - 280nm (Aromatic amino acids) Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases) NADH/NADPH - 340 nm Porphyrins - 400 nm ( Soret band).
  • ➤ Proteins - 280nm (Aromatic amino acids)
  • ➤ Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases)
  • ➤ NADH/NADPH - 340 nm
  • ➤ Porphyrins - 400 nm ( Soret band).
  • ➤ Soret

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presented with pain in the calf muscles on exercise. On biopsy, an excessive amount of glycogen was found to be present in the muscle. What is the most likely enzyme deficiency? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

questions.text: True regarding Mitochondrial DNA is? ( AIIMS May 2017)

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins

questions.correct_answer: B. It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, is maternally inherited, and contains 37 genes encoding essential components of the electron transport chain.

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Protein degradation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells . The proteasome assembly has a central cylindrical hollow core. Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein into small oligopeptides of 5-6 amino acids length
  • ➤ Ubiquitin tagged proteins are immediately broken down inside the proteasomes of the cells
  • ➤ Ubiquitin-tagged proteins are taken into this barrel, and surrounding proteolytic enzymes digest the protein
  • ➤ The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins . It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.
  • ➤ proteasome is a cylindrical structure
  • ➤ degrades polyubiquitinated proteins
  • ➤ It plays the major role in the degradation of proteins, and is particularly associated with disposal of misfolded proteins and regulatory enzymes that have short half-lives.

questions.text: Which among the following serves as cofactor for Glycogen phosphorylase? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pyridoxal Phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is the cofactor for glycogen phosphorylase and is also involved in amino acid metabolism, heme synthesis, and niacin production.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient happens to have pellagra-like eruptions on skin in spring season from the last 5 years with normal HIAA and high aminoaciduria. Indole levels in urine are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hartnup disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pellagra or pellagra like symptoms can result from ( Differential Diagnosis ):
  • ➤ Differential Diagnosis
  • ➤ Niacin (B3) deficiency due to a diet high in maize, which is low in tryptophan. Vitamin B6 deficiency, since the enzyme kynureninase, which catalyzes a step in niacin synthesis from tryptophan, requires B6 as a cofactor. B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms. Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.
  • ➤ Niacin (B3) deficiency due to a diet high in maize, which is low in tryptophan.
  • ➤ Vitamin B6 deficiency, since the enzyme kynureninase, which catalyzes a step in niacin synthesis from tryptophan, requires B6 as a cofactor. B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms.
  • ➤ Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on RNA? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RT-PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RT-PCR is an RNA-based technique that involves reverse transcription of RNA into cDNA followed by PCR amplification, widely used in gene expression analysis.

questions.text: The following histological image is seen in the patient who is complaining of growth failure and abdominal distension. Signs found were anemia, thrombocytopenia and bony pain. Which enzyme is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Beta-Glucocerebroside

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a crumpled tissue paper appearance of cell which is a characteristic feature of Gaucher’s disease. It is a sphingolipidoses and the most common lysosomal storage disease and occur due to deficiency of lysosomal enzyme β-glucocerebrosidase. The substrate glucosylceramide gets accumulated in macrophages causing eccentric nucleus.
  • • Other clinical features are: Bony pain, pathological fracture, hepatosplenomegaly but no mental retardation (as beta-glucosylceramide is not present in brain).
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Sphingomyelinase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Niemann-Pick disease, characterized by the accumulation of sphingomyelin in macrophages. Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurodegeneration, and the presence of foam cells. Niemann-Pick disease often presents with mental retardation.
  • • Option B. Sphingomyelinase:
  • • Option C. Hexosaminidase: This enzyme has two forms, A and B. Deficiency of Hexosaminidase A leads to Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside, primarily affecting neurons. Clinical features include progressive neurodegeneration, a cherry-red spot on the macula, and early death. Deficiency of both Hexosaminidase A and B leads to Sandhoff disease, which presents similarly to Tay-Sachs but with additional visceral involvement.
  • • Option C. Hexosaminidase:
  • • Option D. G-6-phosphatase: Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), characterized by impaired glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Clinical features include severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. Patients often present with a doll-like facies, protuberant abdomen, and growth retardation.
  • • Option D. G-6-phosphatase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease
  • ➤ Gaucher’s Disease

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? ( AIIMS May 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA

options.label: D
options.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.correct_answer: B. Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.
  • ➤ They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased by which of the following? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

  • ➤ Foods rich in Iron are:

Pumpkin Seeds Sprouts Legumes - such as mixed beans, baked beans, lentils and chickpeas Tofu, Quinoa, Dark chocolate

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 5-hydroxytryptamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, is a crucial neurotransmitter synthesized from tryptophan and involved in numerous physiological processes. Its synthesis involves specific enzymatic actions that are targeted pharmacologically to manage various psychiatric

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.
  • ➤ Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 290
